It was never meant to be a 0-100 scale - this was at a time when decimal systems weren’t used for most measurements, or even currency. He based his system around multiples of 12, which were used in many other measurement systems and which we still use to measure time and angles. So 0° = the lowest temperature he could stably measure at the time, and 96° = the body temperature of a healthy person (which we now know is closer to 98.6°). He observed the freezing point of water at 32° using that system, and set the boiling point to be 180° higher (another multiple of 12), then calibrated the whole thing so that all the degree marks lined up on those numbers. The reason you want an increasing scale is because it's important where the 0 ends up.

If you put 0 at a position where the thing that you are measuring isn't at it's lowest (or highest), then you can't do arithmetic with the scale. See what happens? 378 times 2 isn't 377, so it isn't arbitrary whether you go up or down on a scale because it isn't arbitrary where you place your 0.

However, I'm not fond of the fact that to get higher precision than 18-24 degrees (standard room temperature) you need to throw in a decimal. 18.6 degrees rather than 19.2 degrees. Fahrenheit helps with this a bit, making anywhere between 64 and 75 degrees as standard room temperature. That gives 12 different numbers to represent the range rather than 7.

So in THAT way, the best temperature system would be where the freezing point of water was zero, and the melting point of potassium was 100 (63.5 Celsius/146.3 Fahrenheit). That would make the standard room temperature range 28 through 38, or 11 different numbers. This would also allow a two-digit number to represent all temperatures you could expect to find on the surface of the planet, where the freezing point of water had the substantial +/- sign attached depending on what side of that you were. (Only some of the more extreme conditions in the south pole could reach a three-digit number.)

I'm not saying we should implement this different system, just pointing out that there are benefits to many different systems. The main issue with the water/potassium scale is it's a bit odd to compare phase shifts of two different materials for one scale.
